State Of The #Resistance
Need good news to end your long week? Your hard work made a difference. A weekly update of The State Of The #Resistance
Feb 17

Week 4

The #Resistance is alive and well. Here’s what your hard work accomplished in Week 4.

  1. Flynn resigned. A recap of the last few months may be in order, especially because news has moved so fast lately and if you’ve been busy, you might have missed it and feel too embarrassed to ask anyone because it seems like what’s happened might be real important. Don’t worry, we got you covered. Here’s how it went down.
  2. Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn was hand-picked for the National Security Advisor role by the Trump transition team. On the day the Obama Administration announced punitive sanctions against Russia for meddling with the 2016 presidential election (Dec 29, 2016), Flynn placed a call to this dude, and allegedly discussed only pleasantries and other topics customary of a surrogate in a transition team. What actually happened, according to intelligence sources that routinely tap the phones of people like Kislyak, was a substantial discussion about the sanctions and a request for Moscow not to worry because the incoming Trump administration would hold a more favorable position towards Russia. Such a conversation would be a massive break from tradition, and a possible violation of the Logan Act, a 1799 law enacted to prevent private or unauthorized citizens from negotiating foreign policy in contravention of the existing executive’s actions. Commence public denials by all members of the Trump team that such a conversation happened. These denials included Flynn himself, Press Secretary and Second Yeller-at-the-media-in-command Sean Spicer, and the Vice President of the United States in a television interview.
  3. The Washington Post shines a light. WaPo then broke a story revealing that then-Acting Attorney General Sally Yates (remember her?) notified the White House weeks ago that Flynn’s conversation with Kislyak made him a potential target to blackmail, meaning that the White House had been lying to the public about what it knew, when it knew it, and what it picked and chose to tell the American people. Flynn ended up resigning, becoming the shortest tenured National Security Advisor in American history (by a long mile), and a massive embarrassment for the Trump Administration.
  4. You’d think the mess would end there. Nope. Kellyanne Conway went on the Today Show for spin and claimed that it was Flynn’s decision and that he resigned voluntarily for having “misled” Vice President Pence and the President, implying that the Trump Administration was loyal to Flynn til the end. The next morning, Press Secretary Spicer said the opposite: that the President asked Flynn to resign because his trust in Flynn had eroded over past months, meaning that Flynn was fired. Note: Flynn wasn’t in jeopardy of losing his job until the Washington Post, through its incessant, incisive reporting, revealed the extent of the damage.
  5. He’s gone off the reservation. Have a look at the tweets by the President in the last week.

The walls are closing in, fast.

6. Vice Admiral Robert Harward turned down Flynn’s old job. So turns out that the President didn’t just fire someone, he can’t fill a position either. Anyone interested? Anyone?

7. Fox News goes after Trump. Remember when the President said Fox and Friends is “great” a few lines up? Um. This is gonna get awkward.

8. The President is caught in a lie, live. The President, as usual, decided to open a press conference where he knew he was going to get serious questions about one of his blunders (this time it was the Flynn Dumpster Fire) with a comment on his victorious campaign. He claimed that he had won the biggest electoral victory since Ronald Reagan’s election. NBC White House Correspondent Peter Alexander informed the President that 41, 42, and 44 (twice) had bigger margins than he did in 2016. Schadenfreude.

Trump Fact-Checked By Peter Alexander: 'Why Should We Trust You?'
President Trump responded to NBC News' Peter Alexander after he incorrectly stated he had the largest victory margin in…www.nbcnews.com

8. Labor Secretary Nominee Pudzer withdraws. Read this and learn how awful a nominee Andrew Pudzer is for the Labor job. It’s crazy that this guy was nominated for a cabinet position.

9. This is why we fight. CNN President Jeff Zucker believes that the contentious relationship between the President and the fact-respecting news media has only emboldened the press to delve deeper into their source networks and reveal the truth. They call it a “badge of honor.”

Pressure makes them make mistakes. Have a hell of a weekend, and fight on. #Resistance
